headline: One-Pan Cajun Orzo with Sausage
name: One-Pan Cajun Orzo with Sausage
recipeInstructions: In a large deep skillet over medium heat, heat oil. Add onion and pepper and cook until soft, 5 minutes. Add garlic and cook until fragrant, 1 minute more. Add sausage and cook until warmed through and golden, about 2 minutes.  Add orzo and stir to toast for 1 minute. Add diced tomatoes, broth, and cajun seasoning. Season with salt and pepper. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until orzo is cooked through and tender, about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.  Add cream cheese and stir until melted, then stir in green onions.

review.reviewBody: This was very quick to make, and very tasty. I did make changes because my family doesn’t care for spicy foods. Instead of using andouille sausage, I used a smoked chicken Italian sausage, I used 2 tsp of Italian seasoning instead of the Cajun spice, and about a cup of Parmesan cheese instead of cream cheese. After I stirred in the Parmesan cheese, I topped it off with a handful of shredded mozzarella, put the cover back on until the mozzarella melted, and served. My husband and son both liked it a LOT!

This meal had good flavor, but I found myself avoiding the sausage pieces because they were overcooked and rubbery. It might be worth trying this recipe using sliced fresh sausage (you can cut fresh sausages easier if you put them in the freezer for 20 minutes before slicing), but then you’d probably want to start with searing the sausages first, removing them from the pan to cook the peppers and onions, then reintroducing them when you add the liquid ingredients. I imagine it would be delicious with shrimp or chicken as well. I will definitely try making this again, but I won’t be using pre-cooked sausages.
This was delicious, and easy to make. Next time I might try using Rotel instead of fire-roasted tomatoes for an extra bit of heat, but it was still fine just the way it was, too.
My family loved it. I halved the Cajun season to make it less spicy. It still had a kick but not bad. Would make it again - you could add/sub shrimp or other meats/veggies.

Just finished eating a bowl of this awesomeness. What a great idea to use orzo and cook it in with everything else. Love it and so do the kids! I am eating lower sodium, so I used a turkey kielbasa that is lower in salt and only added a tiny bit of himalayan salt in the recipe. My cajun seasoning is homemade and salt-free. This will be in the rotation! I love how fast it is, too. Might add in some shrimp next time.

description: One-Pan Cajun Sausage & Orzo is an easy weeknight dinner with tons of comfort and flavor.
